Wow...One of the best musical nights of my life.  I'd been trying to find this venue called Fusion for about  2 weeks, no one had heard of it and there was no website to be found for it.  Luckily someone from the Allman Brothers site helped me out and told me a general idea of where it's at.  Trying to find more information about the venue, so I could get tickets, I went to www.richmond.com and found this article about Oteil. http://www.richmond.com/ae/output.aspx?ID=3512565&Vertical_ID=3&tier=1&position=1   
On the bottom was a phone number listed.  I called at about 7:50.  The lady said the band starts at 9, but there are only 15 tickets left and they can only be purchased at the door.  So i hurried out the door, and got directions from the lady.  On the way I realized I didn't know whether the exit's off 95 or 64.  I tried calling a friend but got no answer, so I called a girl I worked with who told me to get on 95.  She calls me back and says "actually it's 195" at the exact moment I pass by 195.  So I had to get off on the next exit and come back.  Well I get off on 195 and did something wrong because I ended up going to some tollbooth and driving under 3rd and 7th street.  I managed to get directions from another friend.  I had to drive 10 minutes at least through downtown Richmond.  Looking for 12th street, I pass over 1st, 2nd, 3rd and so forth.  Of course i never saw 11th steet so passed right by 12th.  I come back by and get on 12 street and immediately see the venue.
Found a parking lot and rushed to the venue.  I see Paul Henson walk in a few feet in front of me, Paul being the singer.  I said hey to him, remembering how outgoing and friendly he was when I met him at the Lincoln Theatre, at that time I didn't even know what he looked like, just that I'd listened to quite a few bootlegs with his vox.  Got there and saw i could go upstairs downstairs or straight across to the bar.  I went downstairs and saw a guy standing by a closed door.  Sure enough there were tix left and I gladly paid him my 15 bucks.

For future reference: Fusion website http://www.fusionrichmond.com/
I walk in the venue, and notice one thing...it's very tiny.  It holds only 100 people....so being able to see the band of the caliber of Oteil's band in such a small, intimate venue was quite exciting.  The place had the feel of some sort of 40s jazz club downstairs, almost a private sorta thing, w/o the haze of cigarette smoke.  I decide to pull out a chair in front of where the band would play, since everyone there so far was sitting at tables.  A group of guys come to sit over where I'm at so I move over to let them in.  The guy next to me introduces himself and mentions that he knows Oteil pretty well.  We talk for a bit, then he says "Hey ya know that guy over there, Butch?"  He's pointing to a guy sitting 2 seats from me.  At that moment I realize he does look a bit familiar, but hadn't paid attention.  "He plays for the Dave Matthews Band."  "Ah yeah, Butch Taylor, their keyboardist."  
the band comes out and Oteil gives a shot out to 2 of the guys sitting next to me, including the guy I talked to.  It was a great song with some nice scat work by Oteil and definite good playing by Mark.
Mark Kimbrell comes out playing a strat which sounded fantastic.  Oteil had a bit of a cold.  The band played a lot of jazzier stuff to start off with. The song that sticks out most during the 1st set was a song Oteil said he had to early in the show because there were church folk in the audience (from his church in birmingham alabama) and that they go to bed early.  
During the break, I bought their 2 cds and took them to my car.  On the way back I struck up a conversation with Mark and Paul along with some other guys.  The second set featured an incredible Butter Biscuit, a tune written by Oteil.  Oteil did a vocal scat line from Stevie Wonder's Jesus Children of America along with some bass tags and teases from other tunes.  They also did their Power Of Soul->Back in Black->Ocean (Hendrix/ac-dc/led zepp) medley.  Oteil sang on Power of Soul while the other two songs were just played instrumentally very shortly.  These songs aren't what you'd expect from this band, but they sound great.  They did this medley when I saw them at the Lincoln Theatre.
After the show, Oteil came up to the guys next to me and I just listened to their conversation.  He mentioned they were doing a show for WNCW, the public radio station out of spindale, nc that I used to listen to in high school.  He then mentioned that they're playing Raleigh friday and I let them know I planned on attending the show.  After the show, someone came up adn mentioned they liked my dtb shirt.  I later found out it was the guy that gave me directions and info on the venue from the ABB site, so I got his band's card.  All and all, a wonderful show, but being 12:40 and I wake up in less than 6 hours, I gotta go to sleep.

Here's my analysis of the show even though I wasn't there...First of all Boulder is a terrific town, and I'd like to visit really soon, especially since I'm from the area.  A friend of mine says the Fox Theatre is an awesome venue.

Warren starts off solo with Real Thing, a great tune off the Phil Lesh album that had Warren and Jimmy Herring on guitar.  In My Life, I'm wondering if it's the Beatles tune, I believe Warren may have written a song with that same title.  The rest of the band come out on Warren's great tune Fallen Down.  And then the masterpiece, Patchwork Quilt, one of my favorite tunes written by anyone.  This is when it gets interesting...I shall Be Released, I'm thinking it's the Bob Dylan tune.  I'd love to hear this.  Then two Van Morrison covers, And it Stoned Me as well as Into the Mystic.  The Allmans did Into the Mystic in Raleigh 2 summers ago and it was fantastic, every bit as good as the original.  It's one of Warren's top 10 songs of all time, and another favorite of mine.  Another great Warren original, Lay of the Sunflower which was a collaboration with famed Grateful Dead lyricist Robert Hunter.  Then we have a Warren tune, a Stones cover and a U2 cover.  
The second set seems more rocking....looks like the Beatles cover of I'm So Tired along with Red House.  The encore being Hendrix/SRV classic Little Wing and then the SRV blues staple Pride and Joy.  I'm ready for my Mule, no doubt.

It's been roughly over a week since I moved up to RVA (Richmond, Virginia).  The hardest part so far was the moving aspect.  I decided to move on Tuesday, my old roommate and his gf helpe me pack up and then I drove a U-Haul by myself.  I make 3 stops, and then get to my apartment.  Unload most of my stuff with a little bit of help, and then I try to back my U-Haul in my space more and realize it's dead.  The lights come on, radio, but the engine won't budge.  I'm lucky that it didn't die sooner, so it was towed off.  This past weekend, I came back to Raleigh to get my car.  

My first week of work went pretty well.  The company's a bit swamped with work and really didn't have time to start me on anything until Friday.  I've been trying to learn AutoCAD, which I have no prior experience with, and learning the ins and outs of my job.  So far I've worked on about 5 or 6 projects, and this week I've gone on two trips.  Tuesday we went to a Wal-Mart we're designing stormwater drainage for at Harrisonburg VA, 2 hours away-where James Madison Univ is located, and today we inspected 11 construction sites for VPDES, Virginia Pollution Discharge Elimination System.  We started at 8am and I didn't get home until about 6.  

So far so good, I enjoy the job so far.  This past week has flown by.  A friend of mine did tell me that the first 7 or 8 months is the honeymoon, so I guess the drag of the real world may kick in sometime around then.  I've been pretty busy all the past week, arranging things in my townhouse.  Last night was the first night I was able to come home and just relax, well after my 2nd workout at Gold's Gym.  I've been too busy to really sit down and analyze how things are, I'm sure with more down time I'll be doing just that.  

I do find it kind of odd I was an env tech/science major before I went into env engr, and now I'm working for a land development consultant firm.  How long I see myself doing this kind of job, I'm not really sure.  Yesterday I could see myself do it for several years, but I always envisioned myself doing something with more importance.  What we do is important to a lot of people, because lots and lots of money is involved, but that kind of stuff isn't really relevant to me.  Despite that, I definitely have a drive to become good at what I do.  I haven't had this drive since I was probably in elementary school.  I feel like I haven't really been truly focused at anything schoolwise since then, and now I feel focused, things are making sense and I feel like I'm progressing.  

As for the following days, Friday-for lunch a bunch of us are going to this awesome Mexican restaraunt.  As for after work, I have no idea what I'll get into.  Saturday's the 12th of Feb, a day which I've dread every year for quite a long time...I'll try and start a new checking account and go to the gym.  Sunday, I plan on traveling westward for the Government Mule show in Charlottesville.  I need to go to a show, and nothing could be a better fit than having Mule kick my ass.  I put in the Live-With a Little Help From My friends-which also has Chuck Leavell, derek trucks and marc ford....I gotta see these guys again.

(Richmond, VA-February 9, 2005) -  A Norfolk, Va., legislator says the droopy-drawers bill may be his legacy. 

The Virginia House of Delegates has tentatively approved a bill to crack down on people who wear low-riding pants.

Freshman Norfolk Delegate Algie Howell Jr. introduced the bill at the urging of constituents who are offended by the exposed underwear.

Delegates approved a measure that would allow police to assess a $50 fine on anyone who exposes their below-waist underpants in a "lewd or indecent manner."

Howell said that since he introduced it last month, he's been deluged with calls and e-mails about the issue, mostly positive.

Howell told The Virginian-Pilot that he kept hearing from customers in his barber shop that something needed to be done about young people who wear their pants around their knees, exposing their underwear.

When a House subcommittee took up the matter, the response was sympathetic yet skeptical because of legal issues. It's going to the House floor for a vote.

Droopy-pants bill gets dropped in Virginia Senate


By the Associated Press

Published February 10, 2005

RICHMOND, Va. -- Virginia lawmakers dropped their droopy-pants bill Thursday after the whole thing became just too embarrassing.

The bill, which would have slapped a $50 fine on people who wear their pants so low that their underwear is visible in "a lewd or indecent manner," passed the state House on Tuesday but was killed by a Senate committee two days later in a unanimous vote.

Republican Sen. Thomas K. Norment said news reports implied that lawmakers were preoccupied with droopy pants.

"I find that an indignation, which dampens my humor," Norment said.

Republican Sen. Kenneth Stolle, the committee chairman, called the bill "a distraction."

The committee hearing drew a standing-room-only crowd that included about 75 government students from Surry County High School.

"If people in Florida can wear bikinis, a little underwear showing isn't going to hurt anybody," 17-year-old Elvyn Shaw said.

The bill's sponsor, Democratic Delegate Algie T. Howell, had no immediate comment on the vote. He has said he introduced the legislation on behalf of constituents, including customers at his barber shop, who are offended by exposed underwear.

I saw the Crowes 4 days earlier at the Ritz Theatre...great show.  I still remember the band pulling in on their tour bus and keyboardist Eddie Harsch waving at teh crowd and Rich Robinson, being typical Rich, closes the bus shades.  Ha what an ass.  Before "Miracle to Me" Chris says something to the effect "It'd be a fucking miracle to me if my brother would ever get this damn song right."  Rich shoots him a mean look, but no punches were thrown.  I still remember the blue shirt Bill Monroe tee that Chris was sporting.  Possibly the loudest show I've ever been to but it was pretty damn awesome.

Anyway this 10/17/01 show sounds smoking.  Chris goes off on his typical rant to pump up the crowd before Kickin My Heart Around:
"Like I said it's called rock and mother fucking roll music. Well I went to bed last night kinda frustrated with my playing, especially trying to play along with the Allmans 6-22-00 version of Loan Me a Dime.  The song is originally by Boz Scaggs (who I know absolutely nothing about).  It's a slow minor blues, that Duane Allman played on.  IMO, some of Duane's best work ever.  Anyway there were certain licks that Jimmy Herring and Derek Trucks did that I can't even fathom playing.  However with one of my minute musical breakthroughs I did come up with some stuff.  

The progression's mostly an Am Dm type thing with the cool E+ chord (which instantly makes me think of the opening chord from the Beatles' Oh Darling)...think any minor blues 
Anyway there was a certain chromatic part that I interpreted originally as chords with an Am top and a descending bass note of A, Ab, G, F#.  The part really reminds me a lot of the descending part of Desdemona, off the Allmans last cd.  Anyway I realized that the chromatic part could also be interpreted as Am, E, G, D.  The Ab being the major 3rd of the E chord and the F# being the major 3d of the D chord, basically those two chords being inversions I suppose.  The E chord also can be considered a E augmented with the C note (the minor 3 of the A).  That same C note being the sus4 of the G and the flat 7 of the D.  
This realization really opened up my playing on this song, and probably any other song with this type of progression.  
Over the E I tend to play the 6th note if I do a run in the E major scale, it being the C# (major 3rd of the A chord) is a serious clash, so I have to not get into that habit.  Basically just have to avoid this note no matter what.
The change from the D-Dm brings a lot of interesting scenarios to solo over, the fact that the major 3rd changes to a minor 3rd.  
Over the E I focus on the 3rd (Ab, the natural 7 of the A) which really adds a cool flavor to the song.  
Other cool sounding notes is the flat 5 of the A, which is a blues staple, and the the second (B).  Well one more plateau I've overcome, I'll have fun with this for awhile.  But I really gotta learn more theory.

In four days, I'll be packing up my life and transporting its contents via cardboard enclosures and memories to Richmond.  My outlook on the move I suppose is like entropy and the yin and yang, ever changing and nearly total opposites.  One minute, I'm enthralled by the sense of adventure of moving to unfronted territory (well for me it is) and re-establishing my life and beginning a redefining period in this phenomenom that we simply refer to as life.   The following moment, I'm wishing I had never made that fateful decision and was staying put.
My perspective of the past few years and my life in Raleigh has changed.  I always felt like I had a steady base of friends that I could count on, but the realization of the magnitude of this steady base has finally dawned on me, just the warmth, and the reciprocal gratitude felt mutually between us is something that I now fully realize.  It's not that I was totally oblivious to it, but I know I've met people that have made a positive impact on my life and will continue to do so from here on out.  I'm just finding out how much certain people are there for me and the sincere connection I have made with these people.  Before I felt one of the reasons I wanted to stay in Raleigh was that it was a security blanket, I knew the town and was pretty familiar with it.  The other side of the coin says that life had become monotonous and that change is needed, that a drastic change was what was in order for me to find my niche.  Everyone I know seems to be finding their niche and I'm still looking to carve my own.
All last weekend until yesterday, the thought of leaving just ate me up...almost to where I could feel an emptiness, almost the equivalent of a broken heart.  These days were full of reminiscing and just trying to hold on to every shred of what life once was, whether it is my old college days or just the people I know in Richmond.  Every thought, every shared moment, full of sentimental value that could not be traded for anything else.  I feel like so many people have made a mark on my life.  And for anyone that I said "Let's keep in touch" it is sincerely meant.  
Sometimes the greatest moments taste the most bittersweet, and are sometimes part of the simple things in life.  It's hard to enjoy these greatest moments when I know deep down that I'll be leaving the area and leaving these special moments.  From this I gain a greater appreciation for these times.  They say "absence makes the heart grow fonder" but what about the anticipation of such an absence.  It's the times when I yearn for what I'm used to, the comfort, and all the great times of the past that are going to be the toughest to deal with.  I know moving, there are going to be hard moments, not knowing as many people and just times when I feel like I'm barely paddling on water, I'm making it but it's hard.  I suppose once I'm independent I'll learn to swim and find my shore. 
I've already felt the feeling of being "more alone."  Just this past week when I nearly got stuck driving in the snow in Richmond, I felt the feeling that there aren't as many people that would look out for me if I'm in a bind.  Ever since I could remember, I've always been one to try and do everything on my own, if I'm in a tough situation, just to tough it out and not ask the help of other people.  Since I was 2 years old I've been shrugging things off, for whatever reason, maybe defense mechanism but whatever, it is, that's how I've dealt with things.  But just having that support system, that added cushion, is a very comforting thought.  Being in a somewhat emergency type situation brought the feeling of that solitude, the fact that I wasn't within arm length of outstretched hands.  
So this past week I've cherished every moment I've spent with people, moments that ordinarily seem significant.  Just knowing other people are going through the exact same things in their lives I find very comforting.  And the fact that there are several people that were willing to take time out of their busy schedules to make my final week that more special is very touching to say the least.  To know that there are several people that volunteered to come up and help me move and keep me company on my first weekend in a new place means so much.  This in a way, makes everything harder about moving.  I sometimes ask why am I leaving a good thing?  But I know everything happens for a reason, and for some reason or another, I'm supposed to move away and start a new chapter of the Book of Life in a new city.  Perhaps more awe-inspiring is the thought that I might have made such an impact on peoples' lives that they would offer to help me out and that they tell me they don't want to see me leave.  
Feelings of anticipation and apprehension have been coming hand in hand.  When I signed that one year apt lease it felt exactly like that, I'm signing off one year of my life away.  My outlook on moving is not always like it is right now, sometimes more bleak, sometimes more optimistic, sometimes more exciting.  This is what I find great with myself writing, I'm just letting out how I feel at an exact instant, a snapshot if you will of my mind at this very moment.  Maybe 5 minutes later, the snapshot will be more clear or brighter, perhaps it'll have more questions.  That's it for now, more analytical probes into my head later, think I'll go put on some cds and relax.

Here it is about 11:30 on a Wednesday night.  Today I've been pondering how I'm going to begin this next part of my life.  Right now I feel like there's an unbearable amount of weight on me, a feeling that has been gracisouly absent since my graduation ceremony.  Pretty much everything has been smooth, no pressure, not many responsibilities and just total freedom, nothing tying me down, no deadlines to meet, no homework assignments to appease my professors.

Well I have a deadline approaching.  Last Friday I was notified that Koontz-Bryant, an engineering company in Richmond VA, offered me a a Project Engineer I position within their Residential Engineering Group.  My foot got into the door thanks to an old high school/college buddy that referred me to the company.  The interview I had with them went great, and I was nearly positive that I would get an offer.
The offer is pretty comparable with the entry level salaries of civil/environmental engineers and there are a decent number of benefits-paid vacation, paid sick leave, dental/health insurance, and profit sharing.  The company's great, and the people that I met seemed great.  Just walking around the place, I felt comfortable, like it was a fit.  So what's the problem?...Oh yeah, Richmond is just over 3 hours away from Raleigh, which means either a 6 hour drive everyday or I'll have to relocate.  
At first, it felt great to get that offer, especially right after finding out I passed the 8 hour FE (Fundamentals of Engineering) Exam.  I pretty much felt like I could get any job I wanted....and it's a good feeling getting that first interview out of the way, no need to ever be nervous for another job interview, which surprisingly I wasn't nervous for this first interview, I pretty much had the attitude that I already had the job, real assuring and confident.  


This week I had two interviews.  The first, a company that I had contacted before Thanksgiving break.  Turns out, it is a brand new company that has been around for a year, with two engineers.  They are in desperate need for help, so they contacted me Monday.  The next day, I interviewed with them.  I was a bit weary going to work for such a young company, but I thought it was worth a shot at least to go and interview.  Well I go out with the guy, he takes me out to a Chinese place to eat.  My first impression of him is that he was rather dull and dry.  On the ride over he mentions how he needs someone that can write well.  I tell him that my freshman english teacher tried to persuade me to become an english major and that I used to write for an online music website.  He then tells me how he graduated from UNC with an english degree and went back to NC State to get an engineering degree.  He also said he was a very technical, by the book detail-oriented engineer...from this I gathered he would be quite anal, thus a nightmare to work for.  He then goes on to tell me his disappointment with NC State's Engineering Dept. how when he graduated he had a prestigious degree, the NCSU College of Engineering was ranked 4th in the nation behind MIT, Cal Tech, and a school in Illinois.  He said the school dropped down to 20th in a matter of a couple years after being forced to graduate more minorities and females..after "dumbing down" the curriculum.  yes he did use those words.  So I'm thinking now, why's this guy talking to a guy that graduated with a 2.9 from a dumbed down curriculum.  So along with his other glowingly positive attributes, I would have to worry about feeling intellectually inferior to this guy...not good, I don't need an experienced engineer that I'm working for constantly remind me of how much smarter he is than I am....and on top of that he's probably some grammar freak.  
After listening to him talk for 2 hours, he tells me that either I can give him a number of what I want, or he could make me an offer.  I think I say something like 'OK' because I have no real interest in working for the guy.  The interview gave me quite the headache....oh and the irony, I just got this, the "majority owner" is his partner, a female...since they can get more work...I guess he has to dumb down the engineering practice as well...well in that case I might have a chance....Actually he spoke very highly of his partner.  Anyway by observing how he acted around people, and just talking to him for 2 hours, there is no way I could work for the guy, I would be around him for 40 hours a week nearly.  Not to mention since it's a startup company, he won't be able to provide the benefits that other companies can or probably coudln't pay a comparable salary.  He did mention, that there may be some paycheck "glitches" and that it may not be as a big a deal for me since I'm not married or anything.  I appreciate his honesty, but I don't feel like missing paychecks.  Needless to say, I won't be taking this job, I may e-mail him and just see if he would give me a decent offer.  

This morning, my interview was with McKim and Creed in Cary.  A couple friends of mine knew a guy that worked there.  First impression of the company, the secretary was very nice, and Grant, the person that interviewed me, was a nice guy.  I felt good about this company.  The interview lasted an hour.  He already indicated that he would beat any offer that was made, definite plus.  However, he is still interviewing 4 other people for the job...He asked if I had any CAD experience...unfortunately I did not.  He said it wasn't required, but I immediately felt my chances of landing the job drop.  He told me that if they are interested in me, I would have to go through one or two more interviews.  He would let me know by the end of the week if they would grant me another interview.  Hopefully I will get another interview, as this is easily my best option as of right now.  

What the decision boils down to...do I take a sure thing right now, or do I wait it out and take something in Raleigh?  The cons of moving to Richmond include the moving hassle, the fact I'll have to have a single apartment, utitlity bills will be by myself, and I'd have to eventually buy furniture and entertainment stuff...though I may not get cable, my time could be better spent reading, playing music instead of mindless vegging in front of the boob tube.  The pros with Richmond, my good friend Dan works with, Darin-the guy that would be my boss seems like a great guy, and I had a great feeling walking into the place, it felt like a good fit, and it's a sure thing.  I've heard good things about the Richmond area.  I'll probably visit the area this weekend, since I believe I owe it to myself to at least check it out...if I don't go, I'll probably decline the offer.  Perhaps going and experiencing a new city may bring some excitement into my life and may be needed.  Fresh start may do some good things for me, ya never know.  A week ago I was all for moving up to Richmond, feeling like I need to get out, get a new start, experience new things meet people...life seemed to be getting stagnant.  What I didn't count on were people telling me they wished I'd stick around that they'd miss me, that makes it 10x harder to think of moving.  So pretty much it's back and forth, move not move...and so on.  A balancing act between old ground and new frontier, sure thing vs. waiting it out.  One thing I'm trying to avoid is that whole "You must get a job immediately or you're a failure."  I have a good friend remind me of that, "The world isn't going to end if I don't have a job soon."  He's right...because my prophetic aunt has me convinced that the world is ending anyways and it's due to some off the wall amalgamation of the Wall Street Jews, Roman Catholic Church, the muslims, Tony Blair and some other key ingredients....but that whole theory's worthy of another entry...-^sarcasm by the way (i think some of what she says is a bit loopy)....Anyway point being, if I don't land a job next week, world's not over, which always makes me think of the fear and consumption theory that Michael Moore used and what Trey Parker was saying...if you don't succeed right away you're not going to amount to anything other than a failure.  So I try to look past that, realize there are plenty of opportunites in this area if that's where I want to be, and I'll patiently apply to more jobs....or I'll take the sure thing....this decision hasn't bothered me til today, but it sure is stressing me out a bit right now.

So basically, I have no idea what I'm going to do.  But here I am, if I'm lucky enough to live a century, or perhaps unlucky enough...being that old is unfathomable to me now...I've used up nearly a quarter of my life.  It's an interesting part of my life, having complete freedom (well except for that built up college debt) but uncertain where I will be and what I'll be doing a month from now.  Both scary and at the same time exciting...it's all about perspective, but best way to deal with it I suppose is to welcome both.  
I'll even quote John Mayer, who for the record I believe is a brilliant songwriter, lyricist and a heckuva guitar player...I mean ever hear him do the Stevie Ray and Wes Montgomery stuff, and damn he has some nice tone out of that strat...he just sometimes sings wussy songs and has that annoying breathy voice, but I actually can now enjoy some of his songs in somewhat small doses...I now am less embarassed to admit it now too.  
'Welcome to the real world', she said to me
Condescendingly
' Take a seat, take your life
Plot it out in black and white'

So I guess that's it...I'm plotting out the rest of my life in the real world, setting myself up for a life of working everyday, however I promise not to subject myself to a life I don't enjoy, the second I realize I don't enjoy my work...it'll be off to something else, owning a business perhaps, or pursuing my passion for music, who knows...

			Being Twenty-Something

 

They call it the "Quarter-life Crisis." It is when you stop going along

with the crowd and start realizing that there are a lot of things about

yourself that you didn't know and may not like. You start feeling insecure

and wonder where you will be in a year or two, but then get scared because

you barely know where you are now. You start realizing that people are

selfish and that, maybe, those friends that you thought you were so close

to aren't exactly the greatest people you have ever met and the people you

have lost touch with are some of the most important ones. What you do not

realize is that they are realizing that too and are not really cold or

catty or mean or insincere, but that they are as confused as you.

 

You look at your job. It is not even close to what you thought you would

be doing or maybe you are looking for one and realizing that you are going

to have to start at the bottom and are scared. You miss the comforts of

college, of groups, of socializing with the same people on a constant

basis. But then you realize that maybe they weren't so great after all.

You are beginning to understand yourself and what you want and do not

want.

 

Your opinions have gotten stronger. You see what others are doing and find

yourself judging a bit more than usual because suddenly you realize that

you have certain boundaries in your life and add things to your list of

what is acceptable and what is not. You are insecure and then secure. You

laugh and cry with the greatest force of your life. You feel alone and

scared and confused. Suddenly change is the enemy and you try and cling on

to the past with dear life but soon realize that the past is drifting

"The day" came and passed.  I'd been waiting for several months for the Allman Brothers show.  Having 2nd row seats only quadrupled the anticipation.  I knew I was in for quite a show and wasn't disappointed...well not with the Allmans anyway.  

I met my friend Brett on 6 Forks, ate some food and then headed to Walnut Creek.  We get parked....2 seconds later someone muttered something to his friends about Brett's sticker advertising John Kerry.  The guy was wearing a "Osama Wants You to Vote for Kerry" T-shirt. I had to bite my lip from saying "We also have 2nd row seats!"  We wasted no time in the parking lot and headed for the venue.  We actually heard people yelling Bush propaganda in the parking lot.  Walking through the parking lot, it was evident this isn't the typical Allman crowd.  This crowd was rowdier, yelled "Get r done" at any given chance, and were just plain redneck.  It wasn't hard to spot who came to see Skynyrd, oh yeah Skynyrd opened I forgot, and who came to see the Allmans.  I always knew there was some sort of a rift between Allman fans and Skynyrd fans...I always thought it was something more of my imagination, that I exaggerated it a bit...but in fact walking through the crowd solidified my belief there's a cultural difference.  

We get to our seats, there was an opener playing acoustic guitar and singing, I had no idea there would be someone playing before Skynyrd.  I get to my seat...could not believe it...it was like I was dreaming..."Damn I'm close!!!"  2nd row seats, right in the middle!  We're about 10 feet away from the stage.  

It was obvious most of the people around me were here to see Skynyrd.  The 3 guys turned around to talk to us...they seemed like nice people but...one had about 2 half teeth, so I'll say he had one tooth, the other two had these cowboyish hats, one with a skynyrd bandana around it...they're teeth weren't pretty.  I couldn't believe it.  Right in front of me was your true stereotypical Skynyrd fan.  

At around 7 Lynyrd Skynyrd was to come out.  I decided beforehand I was going to enjoy this to my best ability and not be too judgmental of the band.  Before they came out, they played some redneck cartoon about a guy that was named Dog the Bounty Hunter, I actually think it's going to be a TV show soon.  Anyway it was dumb as hell.  I thought I was at a WWF wrestling match or something along the lines.  Such cheesy introductions.  The guys came out exactly like on their One More From the Road CD...playing verbatim Working For the MCA and I Ain't the One.  I admit being 2 rows away from them playing these songs was a bit of a rush.  I don't consider myself a hardcore Skynyrd fan but they did write some great songs when Ronnie Van Zandt was in the band, something which obviously this version of Skynyrd knows.  They do several songs and I hear something similar to the drum intro my favorite Skynyrd tune "I Know a Little."  Well this band does the song with too much distortion and not enough swing...I didn't enjoy it too much.  This was about 45 minutes into the show and I was bored out of my mind.  The 3 guitars meshed together sounding much like a train wreck and they played all their songs verbatim.  Ronnie's little brother, the singer, kept yelling out crap like "How Ya doing Raleigh-Durham" and who's some real "Skynyrd fans?"  They yelled the Raleigh thing at least 6 or 7 times.  One of their guitarist Ricky Medlocke did everything he could to pump up the crowd, but it was pretty corny in my opinion.  The show looked so rehearsed and overdone...sure it looked like they were having fun.  I mean how many videos of former members of Skynyrd can you have.  How many times can you pay homage to your country and the military and really mean it sincerely.  Oh yeah the rebel flag crap started coming up halfway into the set.  My opinion of Skynyrd show, entertaining, cheesey, some decent guitar work, some not so decenet guitar work, and at times a sloppy sounding show.  To say the least I wasn't impressed by their gimmicks and all their talking about their glory days when they had Collins, Gaines, and Ronnie was singing.  I thought several times during the show Ronnie must be rolling in his grave.  It was quite a disgrace.  They finally did Sweet Home Alabama and Freebird...whew!!! that's finally over....Let's bring some real music.

An older guy next to us during the set break asked us who we came to see.  He was wearing a Allman shirt, and he definitely could sense we were there for the Allmans.  I rapped with him a while as he'd first seen the Allmans in the early 70s.  He had seen them 12 times this year.  He talked about meeting all the guys, even Gregg Allman this year, talked about the archivist Kirk West and some other cool stories over the years.  We asked how he could get off work to see the Allmans.  He said he's paid his dues and he travels a lot for work and plans his travels over seeing concerts.  

Finally 9:00 hits and the Allmans start.  I think there are about 5 people in front of me, about 20,000 behind me...man what a feeling...Man!!!  I'm right in front of Warren Haynes and Oteil Burbridge.  They come out and quite a few people are gone.  They start things off by playing Statesboro Blues, Warren on slide.  Immediately the Allmans sound great.  The sound meshes...I was worried by how bad Skynyrd sounded that I was in a bad spot...nope it was just Skynyrd that sounded bad themselves.  It was apparent how more professional the Allmans sounded.  After seeing Skynyrd play first, I have an even higher appreciation for the Brothers, if that was even possible.

Halfway through the show, Gregg says something along the lines "here's a song that we've gotten requested a few times."  The guy next to me said it's gonna be "Blue Sky."  I told him no way!  I'll bet $100 right now that it's not Blue Sky. See I knew that they hadn't played Blue Sky since Dickey Betts was kicked out of the band back in 1999.  I knew there was no way Gregg Allman would ever sing a Dickey Betts tune at an Allmans show.  Never happening.

You could see the shock in the Allmans fans, no one saw this one coming...well except for the guy next to me.  I had to text message Rick Lollar to let him know Blue Sky.  When Gregg started singing the song after Derek and Warren's solos I had to call and let him hear it on the cell.
